awd_titl_txt: NSF REU-Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates site to create "Pathways Opening World Energy Resources" (REU - POWER)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates site to create "Pathways Opening World Energy Resources" (REU - POWER), located at Northeastern University, Boston MA. The REU-POWER site will provide rising sophomores, juniors and seniors with a summer-based experience working with professors from across the College of Engineering, engaged in research on topics pertaining to the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) Grand Energy Challenge. There is special emphasis on the recruitment of underrepresented minority (URM) students, and because of this, REU-POWER can particularly create professional development programs that address particular barriers of URM STEM populations.   Specifically, REU-POWER will (1) provide annual financial and mentoring support for 10 qualified URM scholars; (2) impact the well-documented U.S. national need for a more diverse energy workforce; and (3) help advance research to make renewable, solar and clean energy more prevalent in society, to help solve the NAE Grand Energy Challenges. The success of the REU-POWER model will be disseminated to other institutions to follow. 

Other unique aspects of the REU-POWER site includes the development of: 1) hands-on short courses with experimental renewable energy labs for all participants; 2) formal mentor training that includes educational modules for mentoring URM engineering students; 3) extensive professional development seminars; 4) formal research training including daily reflection journals, poster presentations and technical writing of a research digest with a faculty member; and 5) recruitment from a unique pool of highly talented URM students that have already expressed interest in energy careers. A primary goal of the REU-POWER site is to excite and engage undergraduate students to pursue careers in the energy field, whether in research labs, industry or to continue their studies in graduate school.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU-POWER program  (2018-2023) provideda total of 36 rising sophomores, juniors and seniors with a paid 10-week summer-based research experience working with professors at Northeastern University (Boston, MA) from across the College of Engineering.  Research topics focused on helping solve the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) Grand Energy Challenge, which represents one of the 14 priority Grand Challenges for Engineering in the 21st Century.  Typical summer research topics included machine learning in solar energy, smart grid operation, building stronger magnets for wind energy, renewable energy storage, and more. There was a particular focus on transcending the barriers and overcoming the challenges to providing ample clean energy to citizens throughout the world.

Energy topics were also studied at cultural perspectives from both wealthier first world nations, such as in the United States, as well as emphasizing third world nation concerns, particularly from countries in Africa.

Throughout the 10-week session, participants were exposed to a dynamic curriculum comprising seminars, hands-on lab experiments, and one-on-one mentorship. The program's uniqueness emerged from its fusion of scientific research, energy policy analysis, and cross-cultural ethical considerations. This approach fostered a sense of excitement and camaraderie among the cohort, ready to contribute to future energy solutions.

Inclusive by design, the REU-POWER program welcomed 36 motivated undergraduate students from various backgrounds. Among these, 39% were first-generation college students, underscoring the program's commitment to accessibility. The participant breakdown by ethnicity revealed 42% Black, 17% Hispanic, 14% Asian, and 28% white students, showcasing a diverse representation that mirrors the global energy challenge's complexity.

 

Intellectual Merit: Forging Pathways through Education and Research:

Sponsored by the NSF, the REU-POWER Program exemplified innovation and exploration in energy-related research. Over its duration, the program empowered 36 undergraduate students, enhancing their research acumen while refining their communication and ethical reasoning abilities. The combination of seminars, workshops, and experiential learning experiences cultivated a deep interest in STEM disciplines.

The program's approach has been multifaceted, combining seminars, workshops, and hands-on experiences to refine the participants' presentation skills, instill ethical considerations, and spark a profound interest in science and mathematics.

 

Broader Impacts: Paving the Way to a Sustainable Future:

Beyond academia, the REU-POWER program played a pivotal role in fostering diversity, education, and societal advancement. By actively engaging underrepresented minorities and first-generation college students, the program contributed to bridging gaps in the energy sector and cultivating future leaders in energy solutions.

The program's adaptability was evident during the Covid-19 pandemic as it seamlessly transitioned to in 2021 to a virtual platform. In all years (2018-2023) REU-POWER exposed participants to an energy boot camp, mentorship opportunities, and comprehensive research training. Students emerged from the 10-week experience not just as researchers, but as resilient problem solvers, equipped to tackle complex real-world issues. Other training initiatives included professional and technical seminars, workshops, and meetings that honed skills and enriched growth.  At the end of all the summer sessions, students presented their research at a public workshop.

 

 

In summary, the REU-POWER program concluded with remarkable success, cultivating a cohort of capable individuals poised to catalyze change in the energy sector. As these emerging leaders embark on their respective journeys, they carry with them an understanding of energy challenges and a strategy to help create a more sustainable and equitable world.
